channel.title: Local variable is not used
channel.description:
[img]http://puu.sh/ddmZc/28b6f25a63.png[/img]
Even though it works does anyone know why it is telling me that the local variable isn't being used? When it is. Just curious.

item.title: Local variable is not used
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

HcoJustin:

Or rather, isWithinDistance should only be accepting other locations. There is no need for it to know about any entities. All it needs to know is if 2 points are within a certain distance of each other.

Skip the middle man. If you want to know the distance between two entities, make it a function of entity. And why have the distance as a parameter? Make it outout the distance directly.

class Entity {
public int getDistanceToEntity(Entity theOtherGuy) {
        //  Code for finding the distance.
    return distance;
    }
...

Then

int distance = attacker.getDistanceToEntity(victim);
if(distance <= 1){
...
}else if(distance <= 5){
...
}else if(distance <= 8){
...
}else{
...
}

You avoid calculating the distance more than necessary, and the code make more sense.

Read full topic

item.title: Local variable is not used
item.dc:creator: @Hyperon Hyperon
item.description:
@Hyperon wrote:

[quote=“Ashi, post:15, topic:548180”][quote author=Hyperon link=topic=667084.msg4460917#msg4460917 date=1417523972]
John, that was useful. I was never really aware of redundancy before but now you’ve explained it as you did I can see that attacker was redundant.

There is a lot of redundant code in rs2server then if this is the case.
[/quote]
Not even, it’s not using OOP properly.[/quote]
He personally helped me understand something I didn’t understand before, I find that useful. Obviously wasn’t useful to you because you already knew.

Read full topic

item.title: Local variable is not used
item.dc:creator: @deathschaos9 DeathsChaos9
item.description:
@deathschaos9 wrote:

I’ll elaborate on the redundancy with a mock class using your code and my own for variables I don’t know of.
Lets examine your code:

As you can see you are calling an Entity and using the same Entity as a parameter.

Lets say getLocation() returns that entities instance of Location.

[code=Java]

class Location {
public boolean isWithinDistance(Entity you, Entity theOtherGuy) {
you.doThis();
theOtherGuy.doesThat();
return true;
}
}[/code]

If you create a new instance of Location for each player, you can reference the Entity from inside the Location class when you initialize the classs.

[code=Java]class Location(Entity e) {
public Entity player = null;
public Location() {
player = e;
}

public boolean isWithinDistance(Entity theOtherGuy) {
    p.doThis();
    theOtherGuy.doesThat();
return true;
}

}[/code]

Only one parameter, no redundancy. Add null checks of course. I’m kinda out of it so yeah… Sorry if this is blob of uselessness.

Read full topic

item.title: Local variable is not used
item.dc:creator: @Hyperon Hyperon
item.description:
@Hyperon wrote:

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:11, topic:548180”]Of course, how could I not see it. The class Entity doesn’t have a function isWithinDistance, which it should have, and thus have to use getLocation().
If you can fix it, fix it.[/quote]

I didn’t actively seek to check this out as of yet, but this might explain why NPCs were attacking from distances with melee and magic when using this.

Read full topic

item.title: Local variable is not used
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

Of course, how could I not see it. The class Entity doesn’t have a function isWithinDistance, which it should have, and thus have to use getLocation().
If you can fix it, fix it.

Read full topic

item.title: Local variable is not used
item.dc:creator: @Hyperon Hyperon
item.description:
@Hyperon wrote:

The NPC is the attacker and the player is the victim.

                @Override
		public void hit(final Mob attacker, final Mob victim) {
			super.hit(attacker, victim);
			
			if(!attacker.isNPC()) {
				return; //this should be an NPC!
			}
			
			NPC npc = (NPC) attacker;
			CombatStyle style = CombatStyle.MAGIC;
			
			int maxHit;
			int damage;
			int randomHit;
			int hitDelay;
			boolean blockAnimation;
			final int hit;

			if(attacker.getLocation().isWithinDistance(attacker, victim, 10)) {
				switch(random.nextInt(1)) {
				case 0:
					style = CombatStyle.MELEE;	
					break;
				case 1:
					style = CombatStyle.MAGIC;
					break;
				
				}
			}
			
			switch(style) {
			case MELEE:
				Animation anim = attacker.getAttackAnimation();
				attacker.playAnimation(anim);
				
				hitDelay = 2;
				blockAnimation = true;
				maxHit = npc.getCombatDefinition().getMaxHit();
				damage = damage(maxHit, attacker, victim, attacker.getCombatState().getAttackType(), Skills.ATTACK , Prayers.PROTECT_FROM_MELEE, false, true);
				randomHit = random.nextInt(damage < 1 ? 1 : damage + 1);
				if(randomHit > victim.getSkills().getLevel(Skills.HITPOINTS)) {
					randomHit = victim.getSkills().getLevel(Skills.HITPOINTS);
				}
				hit = randomHit;
				break;
	
			default:
			case MAGIC:
			
			    final int gfxDelay;
			    //final int clientSpeed;
			    
			    if(attacker.getLocation().isWithinDistance(attacker, victim, 1)) {
					//clientSpeed = 70;
					gfxDelay = 80;
				} else if(attacker.getLocation().isWithinDistance(attacker, victim, 5)) {
					//clientSpeed = 90;
					gfxDelay = 100;
				} else if(attacker.getLocation().isWithinDistance(attacker, victim, 8)) {
					//clientSpeed = 110;
					gfxDelay = 120;
				} else {
					//clientSpeed = 130;
					gfxDelay = 140;
				}
				
				hitDelay = (gfxDelay / 20) - 1;
				
				attacker.playAnimation(Animation.create(5579));
				World.getWorld().submit(new Tickable(hitDelay) {
					@Override
					public void execute() {
					    victim.playGraphics(Graphic.create(78, gfxDelay, 0));
					    this.stop();
					}			
				});
				
				blockAnimation = false;
				maxHit = 50;
				damage = damage(maxHit, attacker, victim, AttackType.MAGIC, Skills.MAGIC , Prayers.PROTECT_FROM_MAGIC, false, false);
				randomHit = random.nextInt(damage < 1 ? 1 : damage + 1);
				if(randomHit > victim.getSkills().getLevel(Skills.HITPOINTS)) {
					randomHit = victim.getSkills().getLevel(Skills.HITPOINTS);
				}

				hit = randomHit;
				break;
			}		
			
			attacker.getCombatState().setAttackDelay(5);
			attacker.getCombatState().setSpellDelay(5);
			
			World.getWorld().submit(new Tickable(hitDelay) {
				@Override
				public void execute() {
					victim.inflictDamage(new Hit(hit), attacker);
					smite(attacker, victim, hit);
					recoil(attacker, victim, hit);
					this.stop();
				}			
			});
			vengeance(attacker, victim, hit, 1);
			
			victim.getActiveCombatAction().defend(attacker, victim, blockAnimation);
		}

Read full topic

item.title: Local variable is not used
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“Hyperon, post:8, topic:548180”][quote author=DeathsChaos9 link=topic=667084.msg4460820#msg4460820 date=1417480147]
Looking at that block of code clientSpeed is never used. It’s defined but never used in the program except to change its value. However Eclipse does generate that warning wrongly occasionally but we would need to see all of the code to determine if that was the case or not.

Also to point out some redundancy you’re making a call to a method using attacker and sending the same entity as a parameter; no need, just make local changes inside the class.

[size=8pt]Typed up as t4 and Bowser replied, sorry for reiterating their words.[/size]
[/quote]

Thanks for the reply. I looked a lot more carefully and it wasn’t being used. Only gfxDelay was. It’s actually a class for a NPC that attacks with melee and magic. Not sure I understand the redundancy.

[/quote]
I see that you’re casting a spell. Are the first attacker the spell and the second attacker the actual player casting the spell? That might explain the redundancy.
Of course I might be wrong, as I’ve never written a line of code for a RS server.

Read full topic
